qas.question: At what temperature does a thermal radiator most efficiently produce light?
What is the upper limit for LER of an incandescent lamp?
What type of radiation makes up the majority of tungsten filament emissions?
What is the flaw in the color of light produced by an incandescent bulb?

answers.text: the light emitted does not appear white,

qas.question: What is the theoretical LER value of tungsten at its melting point?

plausible_answers.text: The spectrum emitted by a blackbody radiator at temperatures of incandescent bulbs

qas.question: What appears white to the human eye when it is emitted?
What is the lower limit for LER of an incandescent lamp?
What does not radiate mostly infrared radiation at temperatures where they remain solid?
What is not infrared or ultraviolet?
What known material can be used as a filament at 95 lumens per watt?

context: <b5_0>The spectrum emitted by a blackbody radiator at temperatures of incandescent bulbs<b5_0/> does not match the sensitivity characteristics of the human eye; <a3_0>the light emitted does not appear white,<a3_0/> and most is not in the range of wavelengths at which the eye is most sensitive. <b7_0>Tungsten filaments<b7_0/> radiate mostly <a2_0>infrared radiation<a2_0/> at temperatures where they remain solid – below 3,695 K (3,422 °C; 6,191 °F). Donald L. Klipstein explains it this way: "An ideal thermal radiator produces visible light most efficiently at temperatures around <a0_0><b6_0>6,300 °C<b6_0/><a0_0/> (6,600 K; 11,400 °F). Even at this high temperature, a lot of the <b8_0>radiation<b8_0/> is either infrared or ultraviolet, and the theoretical luminous efficacy (LER) is 95 lumens per watt." <b9_0>No known material<b9_0/> can be used as a filament at this ideal temperature, which is hotter than the sun's surface. An upper limit for incandescent lamp luminous efficacy (LER) is around <a1_0><a4_0>52 lumens per watt<a4_0/><a1_0/>, the theoretical value emitted by tungsten at its melting point.
